title: Chapter 185
content: # Chapter 185 Yubadakan ranked among the most prosperous cities in the Harken Kingdom. Seventy thousand residents called it home, drawn by aggressive capital investment and shrewd governance. High-level hunting grounds ringed the city walls, pulling in a constant tide of adventurers. The markets never emptied. Gold flowed like water. The lord who collected over 1.5 million gold each month from this economic engine wasn't some NPC noble. It was Zibal. "Kukukul! You looked down on Grid. How's that working out for you?" Inside Yubadakan Castle, Asuka leaned back in her chair. The 12th executive of the Snake Guild wore a savage grin. "You laughed when Black Teddy and I got demolished. But you?" She slapped the table. "Watching that cat beat down your drake was the most fun I've had in months!" The memory still burned. Right after the Pope Drevigo raid, when she'd been part of the Tzedakah Guild, she'd fought Grid alongside Black Teddy, Box, and Toban. They'd been slaughtered. Zibal had mocked her for weeks. But now? Grid had proven himself impossible to ignore. Zibal had felt that same sting of defeat. The reversal tasted sweet. *Ten years of stress, gone.* Asuka couldn't stop smiling. "How does it feel? Getting crushed by someone you dismissed as trash?" Box shifted in his seat. "Asuka, maybe dial it back a littleâ€”" "I'm sorry." The words cut through the tension. Zibal bowed his head to Asuka. The thirteen executives watched in silence. "I underestimated Grid. Making fun of you was wrong. I apologize." Asuka wasn't petty. Seeing Zibal acknowledge his mistake in front of the entire leadership council satisfied her completely. "Well, fine. I'll be generous and forgive your ignorance." "Thank you." The atmosphere settled. The executives, however, remained grim-faced. One of them cleared his throat. "Master, public opinion has turned toxic since the National Competition." "You're the face of the Snake Guild," another added. "Your reputation affects all of us. Focus on damage control." A third executive shook his head. "No. Get your third advancement class first. The gap between you and Kraugel and Grid is widening." "I heard Hurent and Lauel both declined our offers?" A woman tapped her fingers on the armrest. "Finding replacements is critical." "What about Katz?" someone suggested. "He's been training obsessively since Bondre beat him. He's probably grown." "The guild's morale is shot after seeing the Tzedakah Guild's strength. The members look to you, Master, not to us executives." The debate continued. Each executive offered their vision for Zibal's path forward, their ideas for strengthening the guild. Zibal stared at the table, barely listening. *Grid.* Yesterday's National Competition had been supposed to be Zibal's stage. Millions of eyes watching worldwide. He would shine. The Snake Guild would explode in prestige and recruitment. Grid had stolen all of it. The most brilliant performer wasn't Zibal. It was Grid. Everyone talked about the Tzedakah Guild now, not the Snake Guild. Their rivals would grow at an exponential rate. *The number of users migrating to Bairan is already out of control.* Some of them were talents he'd been courting. Like Lauel. *This can't continue.* His plan had always been clear. Dominate the Harken Kingdom as a foundation. Money, talent, military might. Use wealth to recruit the best, then leverage their strength to conquer territory. Simple. The National Competition had taught him something crucial, though. Money wasn't enough. The reason was obvious. *Items.* Grid's black greatsword and blue greatsword, slicing through top rankers like they were made of paper. The knuckles that let Regas demolish Chris. Pon's red spear that had nearly killed Regas outright. The sheer power of those four weapons haunted him. He wanted them. Every user who'd watched the competition felt that same gnawing desire. Lauel had gone to Grid after seeing those items. At this rate, Grid would monopolize all the talent on the continent. One executive's comment snapped Zibal back to attention. "Should we contact Panmir?" Panmir. The 1st ranked blacksmith. Before Grid's emergence, every major guild had pursued him relentlessly. Pagma's Descendant had overshadowed him completely. "I've located him. He's in the city of dwarves." "Dwarves?" Dwarves were born blacksmiths. Their entire species produced craftsmen of extraordinary skill. They were also insufferably arrogant, treating human smiths like incompetent children. How could Panmir be staying in their city? The executives exchanged glances. "He must have earned their recognition. He might be doing a hidden class change quest." "Interesting." A handful of dwarves could grant life to items. The species as a whole excelled at gunpowder engineering. Pagma might be the superior all-around blacksmith, but dwarves surpassed him in specialized fields. If Panmir inherited dwarven techniques... *He'd be Grid's only real rival.* They had to recruit him. Zibal stood abruptly. "I'll go meet Panmir personally." The outcome proved successful. Zibal secured Panmir's allegiance, and the Snake Guild's explosive growth began. --- The Yatan Church's Third Temple stood amid the ruins of the Bonkost Principality. Inside, the Yatan Servants gathered in their black robes. Yura stood among them. "The successor to Priest Malacus has been chosen." Since the Tzedakah Guild and Grid had killed Malacus, the church's rituals had stalled. Their power had waned. Now a new priest took the vacant seat. *Level 420?* Yura studied the replacement with barely concealed shock. The new priest's level exceeded Malacus by a hundred. *A fourth advancement NPC.* The same tier as the Second Servant and Third Servant. Neberius's eventual replacement would probably match this level. The question that gnawed at her was simple. *How strong is the First Servant?* She'd never met them. Grid needed God Yatan's blessing for his quest, but she still hadn't figured out how to help. The Second Servant, Likaos, stepped forward. "Eighth Servant." His voice echoed in the stone hall. "You are too weak to display God Yatan's grandeur. Embark on the Path of Penance and grow stronger." > [The quest 'Path of Penance' has been created.] > **[Path of Penance]** > Difficulty: SS > Meet the First Servant unharmed. > Quest Clear Conditions: ?? > Quest Failure: ?? The description was pathetically sparse for an SS-difficulty quest. Yura felt a headache building. *This is going to be brutal.* Still, she'd finally qualified to meet the First Servant. Tension and anticipation coiled in her chest. "For the sake of God Yatan," she murmured. By Satisfy's worldview, she was unquestionably evil. --- "Thanks for your hard work." At S Broadcasting Station in Ilsan, Youngwoo stood the moment the talk show wrapped. The main host, PDs, and staff members swarmed him with smiles and handshakes. "You did an amazing job." "The broadcast turned out great because of you." One PD grabbed his hand. "I'll see you next time. Let me buy you dinner." Another grinned. "Are you logging into Satisfy the second you get home? Please reveal your level!" Satisfy had revolutionized the world. The first true virtual reality game, surpassing all existing technology by decades. Over two billion users. It had woven itself into the fabric of the global economy. Its influence touched every industry, every country. Koreans felt immense pride that this masterpiece had been created in South Korea. But there was a problem. South Korea had been a gaming powerhouse in the past, but those days were long gone. Satisfy was Korean-made, but most Korean players struggled to compete. American, French, Canadian, and Chinese users dominated the content. South Korea had Yura and Peak Sword, but two stars weren't enough. The Korean public felt that absence like a wound. Why were they weak in their own game? The game the whole world played? It stung. Then, one month ago, everything changed. Shin Youngwoo entered the National Competition as a Korean representative. He won three gold medals. His dominance was absolute, overwhelming. He quenched Korea's thirst in a single stroke. Youngwoo became a national hero overnight. Every Korean loved him. His popularity exceeded Park Jisung and Kim Yuna at their peaks. He rivaled Yura herself. Any broadcast featuring Youngwoo guaranteed high ratings. Products he endorsed flew off shelves. He'd become the blue chip of the advertising industry. Broadcasters and advertisers fought over him. But Youngwoo was busy. He needed at least fourteen hours a day in Satisfy. *Broadcasts are exhausting.* To make real money in Satisfy, Youngwoo needed to craft level 200 items with at least a Unique rating. But he couldn't produce Unique items on command. Sometimes he'd spend an entire week and get a single Epic item to show for it. Meanwhile, one broadcast paid tens of millions of won. One CF commercial paid hundreds of millions. Yet Youngwoo hated broadcasts and advertising. At first, appearing on TV had been exciting. That novelty had worn off fast. Broadcasts were difficult because he was plain and terrible at improvisation. CFs required shooting the same scene dozens of times, exposing his lack of acting talent and poor concentration. He'd started losing hair from the stress. Playing Satisfy was infinitely preferable. *It's like chewing on pine needles.* Time spent in Satisfy was more profitable than time on broadcasts anyway. Even Rare and Epic items generated steady income. *Plus my production skills improve.* Higher production skill levels meant better items. Youngwoo had decided to quit broadcasting and focus on Satisfy. Yura's advice had helped solidify that choice. *Minimize image consumption.* She'd warned that overexposure would dilute his influence. Youngwoo agreed. From now on, he'd only do broadcasts and CFs when absolutely necessary. "I hope we can work together again soon," the PD said. Youngwoo gave a noncommittal shrug. "If I have time." He left the eager PD behind and walked briskly to the parking lot. Sliding into 23, he checked the rearview mirror. "Phew. It's getting better, right?" The past month had been hell. He'd barely slept, working frantically to handle the tax bomb. Fourteen hours a day in Satisfy making items, six hours doing broadcasts or advertisements. Four hours of sleep if he was lucky. The stress-induced hair loss had accelerated to the point where he'd feared going full bald like some cursed Japanese yokai. But he'd been taking medication religiously, and Yura had connected him with a good tax accountant. The situation was improving. Hair had started growing back on the bare patches. "Alright. Soon I'll be completely fine." *Buaang!* The engine roared, as if 23 sensed its master's improved mood. The car pulled out of the lot. Destination: home. Three months until his new building was completed. Until then, Youngwoo's family remained in their original house.
